text: Who is traditionally identified as the 'Preacher' (Qoheleth), the author of Ecclesiastes?
verseText: The words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.

text: What phrase is famously repeated throughout Ecclesiastes to describe life 'under the sun'?
verseText: Meaningless! Meaningless! says the Preacher. Meaningless! Meaningless! Everything is meaningless.

text: According to Ecclesiastes 1, what happens to generations and the earth?
options: Generations last forever, the earth changes
Generations come and go, the earth remains forever
Both generations and the earth pass away
Both generations and the earth are eternal
verseText: A generation goes, and a generation comes, but the earth remains forever.

text: What does the Preacher conclude about wisdom and knowledge in Ecclesiastes 1?
options: With much wisdom comes much sorrow
verseText: For in much wisdom is much vexation, and he who increases knowledge increases sorrow.

text: Ecclesiastes 3 begins with the famous passage, 'For everything there is a...'
verseText: For everything there is a season, and a time for every matter under heaven:

text: What does Ecclesiastes 3:11 say God has made beautiful in its time and set in the human heart?
verseText: He has made everything beautiful in its time. Also, he has put eternity into man's heart, yet so that he cannot find out what God has done from the beginning to the end.

text: What does Ecclesiastes 4:9 state is better than one?
verseText: Two are better than one, because they have a good reward for their toil.

text: What warning does Ecclesiastes 5:2 give regarding speaking before God?
options: Do not be rash with your mouth or hasty in heart
verseText: Be not rash with your mouth, nor let your heart be hasty to utter a word before God, for God is in heaven and you are on earth. Therefore let your words be few.

text: According to Ecclesiastes 9:11, the race is not always to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, because what happens to them all?
verseText: Again I saw that under the sun the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, nor bread to the wise, nor riches to the intelligent, nor favor to those with knowledge, but time and chance happen to them all.

text: What is the final conclusion reached by the Preacher in Ecclesiastes 12?
options: Fear God and keep his commandments
verseText: The end of the matter; all has been heard. Fear God and keep his commandments, for this is the whole duty of man.

text: The Preacher explored pleasure and laughter as sources of meaning. What was his conclusion about them?
options: They are ultimately meaningless or madness
verseText: I said in my heart, “Come now, I will test you with pleasure; enjoy yourself.” But behold, this also was vanity. I said of laughter, “It is mad,” and of pleasure, “What use is it?”

text: After pursuing great projects, wealth, and pleasures, what did the Preacher find when he looked back on his labor?
options: It was all vanity and striving after wind
verseText: Then I considered all that my hands had done and the toil I had expended in doing it, and behold, all was vanity and a striving after wind, and there was nothing to be gained under the sun.

text: What advantage did the Preacher see that wisdom has over folly?
options: Wisdom leads to wealth, folly to poverty
Wisdom is like light, folly like darkness
verseText: Then I saw that there is more gain in wisdom than in folly, as there is more gain in light than in darkness.

text: Despite wisdom's advantage, what common fate awaits both the wise man and the fool, according to the Preacher?
verseText: For of the wise as of the fool there is no enduring remembrance, seeing that in the days to come all will have been long forgotten. How the wise dies just like the fool!

text: Ecclesiastes lists specific times for various activities (e.g., 'a time to be born, and a time to die'). What is the overarching point of this list?
options: Humans can control the timing of all events
There is an appropriate and appointed time for everything
Some activities are more important than others
verseText: For everything there is a season, and a time for every matter under heaven: a time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up what is planted...

text: What does the Preacher observe about the tears of the oppressed and their lack of a comforter?
options: The oppressed find comfort in their suffering
It is a grievous evil under the sun
verseText: Again I saw all the oppressions that are done under the sun. And behold, the tears of the oppressed, and they had no one to comfort them! On the side of their oppressors there was power, and there was no one to comfort them.

text: Why does Ecclesiastes say that two are better than one?
options: They have a good reward for their toil
verseText: Two are better than one, because they have a good reward for their toil.

text: What specific benefit of companionship is mentioned regarding falling down?
options: One can lift up his fellow
They learn to be more careful
verseText: For if they fall, one will lift up his fellow. But woe to him who is alone when he falls and has not another to lift him up!

text: What metaphor is used in Ecclesiastes 4 to describe the strength of companionship?
verseText: And though a man might prevail against one who is alone, two will withstand him—a threefold cord is not quickly broken.

text: When going to the house of God, what does Ecclesiastes 5 advise is better than offering the sacrifice of fools?
verseText: Guard your steps when you go to the house of God. To draw near to listen is better than to offer the sacrifice of fools, for they do not know that they are doing evil.

text: What reason does Ecclesiastes give for letting your words be few before God?
options: God is in heaven and you are on earth
Few words are easier to remember
verseText: Be not rash with your mouth, nor let your heart be hasty to utter a word before God, for God is in heaven and you are on earth. Therefore let your words be few.

text: What does Ecclesiastes say about the relationship between the love of money and satisfaction?
options: He who loves money will never be satisfied with money
verseText: He who loves money will not be satisfied with money, nor he who loves wealth with his income; this also is vanity.

text: What grievous evil does the Preacher observe regarding wealth kept by its owner?
options: It is kept to the owner's hurt
verseText: There is a grievous evil that I have seen under the sun: riches were kept by their owner to his hurt,

text: How does a person leave the world compared to how they came into it, according to Ecclesiastes?
verseText: As he came from his mother's womb he shall go again, naked as he came, and shall take nothing for his toil that he may carry away in his hand.

text: What does Ecclesiastes recommend as good and fitting for people to do during the few days God gives them?
options: To eat, drink, and find enjoyment in their toil
verseText: Behold, what I have seen to be good and fitting is to eat and drink and find enjoyment in all the toil with which one toils under the sun the few days of his life that God has given him, for this is his lot.

text: What is considered better than precious ointment or the day of birth, according to Ecclesiastes 7?
verseText: A good name is better than precious ointment, and the day of death than the day of birth.

text: Where is it considered better to go, the house of mourning or the house of feasting, and why?
options: Mourning, because it is the end of all mankind
verseText: It is better to go to the house of mourning than to go to the house of feasting, for this is the end of all mankind, and the living will lay it to heart.

text: What effect does sorrow have on the heart compared to laughter, according to Ecclesiastes 7?
options: By sadness of face the heart is made glad (or better)
verseText: Sorrow is better than laughter, for by sadness of face the heart is made glad.

text: What offers protection similar to the protection offered by money, according to Ecclesiastes?
verseText: For the protection of wisdom is like the protection of money, and the advantage of knowledge is that wisdom preserves the life of him who has it.

text: What specific advantage does wisdom provide to the one who possesses it?
verseText: For the protection of wisdom is like the protection of money, and the advantage of knowledge is that wisdom preserves the life of him who has it.

text: Ecclesiastes advises against being overly righteous or overly wise. Why?
verseText: Be not overly righteous, and do not make yourself overly wise. Why should you destroy yourself?

text: What conclusion does the Preacher reach about the righteousness of people on earth?
options: There is no one on earth who is righteous and never sins
verseText: Surely there is not a righteous man on earth who does good and never sins.

text: What advice is given regarding paying attention to all the words people speak?
options: Do not take to heart all the things people say
verseText: Do not take to heart all the things that people say, lest you hear your servant cursing you.

text: What observation does Ecclesiastes 8 make about the timing of judgment for evil deeds?
options: Sentence against evil is executed swiftly
Sentence against evil is never executed
Because sentence is not executed speedily, people do evil
verseText: Because the sentence against an evil deed is not executed speedily, the heart of the children of man is fully set to do evil.

text: Despite observing that righteous people sometimes suffer like the wicked, what does the Preacher ultimately believe about those who fear God?
options: It will be well with them
Their fate is the same as the wicked
verseText: Though a sinner does evil a hundred times and prolongs his life, yet I know that it will be well with those who fear God, because they fear before him.

text: What common event happens to the righteous and the wicked, the good and the evil, the clean and the unclean?
options: They all share the same fate (death)
verseText: It is the same for all, since the same event happens to the righteous and the wicked, to the good and the evil, to the clean and the unclean, to him who sacrifices and him who does not sacrifice.

text: What advice does Ecclesiastes 9 give for enjoying life's simple pleasures, like eating and drinking?
options: Do it with a joyful heart, for God approves
verseText: Go, eat your bread with joy, and drink your wine with a merry heart, for God has already approved what you do.

text: What should one do with all their might while they are alive, according to Ecclesiastes 9?
options: Whatever your hand finds to do
verseText: Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with your might, for there is no work or thought or knowledge or wisdom in Sheol, to which you are going.

text: Why is there no work, thought, knowledge, or wisdom in Sheol (the grave)?
options: Because the dead are busy elsewhere
Because Sheol is a place of learning
Because activity and consciousness cease at death (in the context of the book)
verseText: Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with your might, for there is no work or thought or knowledge or wisdom in Sheol, to which you are going.

text: Ecclesiastes tells a story of a poor wise man who saved a city. What happened to him afterward?
options: He was rewarded with great riches
verseText: But there was found in it a poor, wise man, and he by his wisdom delivered the cityscape. Yet no one remembered that poor man.

text: What does Ecclesiastes say is better: the quiet words of the wise or the shouting of a ruler among fools?
options: The quiet words of the wise
verseText: The words of the wise heard in quiet are better than the shouting of a ruler among fools.

text: What small thing can outweigh wisdom and honor, according to Ecclesiastes 10?
verseText: Dead flies make the perfumer's ointment give off a stench; so a little folly outweighs wisdom and honor.

text: What practical advice does Ecclesiastes 11 give regarding generosity and investment, using the metaphor of bread on water?
options: Cast your bread upon the waters (be generous/invest)
verseText: Cast your bread upon the waters, for you will find it after many days.

text: Why should one 'divide portions' or diversify their efforts, according to Ecclesiastes 11?
options: Because you do not know what disaster may happen
verseText: Give a portion to seven, or even to eight, for you know not what disaster may happen on earth.

text: What should young people remember in the days of their youth, before the 'days of trouble' come?
verseText: Remember also your Creator in the days of your youth, before the evil days come and the years draw near of which you will say, “I have no pleasure in them”;

text: Ecclesiastes 12 uses several metaphors (darkened sun, trembling keepers, grinding maids) to describe what process?
options: The process of aging and death
verseText: ...before the sun and the light and the moon and the stars are darkened and the clouds return after the rain, in the day when the keepers of the house tremble, and the strong men are bent...

text: What happens to the 'dust' and the 'spirit' when a person dies, according to Ecclesiastes 12?
options: Dust returns to earth, spirit returns to God
Spirit ceases to exist, dust remains
verseText: and the dust returns to the earth as it was, and the spirit returns to God who gave it.

text: How are the words of the wise described in Ecclesiastes 12, likening them to tools used by shepherds?
options: Like goads and firmly fixed nails
verseText: The words of the wise are like goads, and like nails firmly fixed are the collected sayings; they are given by one Shepherd.

text: What warning does the Preacher give about making many books?
options: There is no end, and much study is a weariness
verseText: My son, beware of anything beyond these. Of making many books there is no end, and much study is a weariness of the flesh.

text: Ultimately, what does the Preacher identify as the 'whole duty of man'?
options: To fear God and keep His commandments
verseText: The end of the matter; all has been heard. Fear God and keep his commandments, for this is the whole duty of man.
